module.p: leòr satiety, sufficiency, enough (sometimes leòir in older usage) is an indeclinable, feminine simple common noun. It behaves in many respects like a generic quantity noun expressing a sufficient quantity.

In traditional usage, leòr functions like other generic quantity nouns, with the exception that it needs a possessive determiner as pre-specifier –
mo leòr feòla my fill of meat / enough meat (for me)
an leòr de na h-ùbhlan their fill of the apples / enough of the apples (for them)

Note that this construction means one’s fill or as much as one needs/wants and that it normally functions as the object of verbs such as ith eat, òl drink, gabh take, faigh get, thoir (do) give, or as the subject of bi aig have.

cf. làn
complement, fill, sàth
fill, satiety, surfeit.

section.p:
On its own –
Dh’òl Raonaid a leòr. Rachel drank her fill / enough.
Tha ar leòr againn. We have plenty / enough.
An d’fhuair thu do leòr?
Did you get enough? td. 393
An am priobadh na sùla fhuair e-fhèin ann a seilear-fhìon mòr far an robh na trì cailleachan air an dòigh ag òl a[n] leòr [...].
In the blink of an eye, he found himself in a big wine cellar where the three old women were content drinking their fill. td. 56

With a genitive modifier –
Dh’òl Raonaid a leòr uisge. Rachel drank her fill of water / plenty of water.
Tha ar leòr chon againn. We have enough / plenty of dogs.
Bha a leòr airgid aige.
He had enough money. td. 393
Shaodaicheadh e fhéin iad ás deigh sin, suas am monadh, far an òladh iad an leòr uisge san allt, agus far an laigheadh iad [...] gu feasgar.
He would drive them after that, up the moor, where they would drink their fill of water in the burn, and where they would lie [...] till evening. td. 32
Bha mi air a bhith muigh ag òl an oidhche roimhe còmhla ri[s] na balaich agus cha robh mo leòr cadail agam.
I had been out drinking the night before with the boys and I did not get enough sleep. td. 355
Fhuair mi mo leòr de dh’òrain a-raoir.
I got (more than) enough songs last night. td. 246 Note the use of ‘de’ here rather than plain genitive.
Dhìrich e gu bàrr a’ bhalla cloiche a bha timcheall an taighe agus thog e deilbh dhen a h-uile càil a chitheadh e tro na craobhan. [...] Nuair a bha a leòr de dheilbh aige, chaidh e gu doras an taighe agus bhuail e an clag.
He climbed to the top of the stone wall that surrounded the house and he took pictures of everything he could see through the trees. [...] When he had enough pictures, he went to the door of the house and rang the bell. td. 66 Note the use of ‘de’ here rather than plain genitive.

The preposition de with a definite noun –
Dh’òl Raonaid a leòr den fhìon. Rachel drank her fill of the wine.
Dh’ith sinn ar leòr de na h-ùbhlan sin. We ate our fill of those apples.
Dh’itheadh iad a[n] leòr de’n t-suagaraid de mhin-eòrna agus geir, a bha air a bhith a’ bruich ann an clùd ann am poit le bùrn goileach an taic an teine airson sia uairean a thìde.
They would eat their fill of the gloop of barley meal and grease, that had been cooked in a cloth in a pot of boiling water beside the fire for six hours. td. 312–3

With a prepositional pronoun –
Dh’òl Raonaid a leòr dheth. Rachel drank her fill of it.
Tha ar leòr againn dhiubh. We have enough of them.
“Tha amharas agam gum beil hearòin air bòrd. Bha a leòr dheth aig an fhear ud agus bha e dranndan mu dhèidhinn pocannan air falach fo làr cèaban a’ sgiobair.”
“I suspect that there is heroin on board. That man had plenty of it and was muttering about sacks hidden under the floor of the captain’s cabin.” td. 313

module.p:
gu leòr enough, plenty (lit. to sufficiency) is a prepositional phrase that can be used to modify (and quantify) a preceding noun –
Dh’òl Raonaid fìon gu leòr. Rachel drank enough wine.
Tha coin gu leòr aig Màiri. Mary has enough dogs.
Nuair a phòs an dithis òg bha fealla-dhà gu leòr anns an taigh-chèilidh.
When the young couple married there was plenty of fun in the pub. td. 115
Cha tigeadh duine dhan taigh-fhaire gu beul na h-oidhche. Bha tìde gu leòr agam airson smaoineachadh.
No-one would come to the wake-house until dusk. I had plenty time to think. 19
“Gheibh thusa duaisean gu leòr fhathast, a ghràidh,” ars ise.
“You will get enough prizes soon, dear,” she said. td. 72

However, gu leòr cannot be used with a definite noun, in a partitive sense – Dh’òl Raonaid am fìon gu leòr for Rachel drank enough of the wine (cf. the correct form gu leòr den fhìon). Also, leòr is never pre-specified by a possessive determiner in this expression – Tha coin gu mo leòr agam for I have enough dogs (cf. the correct form coin gu leòr).

section.p:
Examples from Gairm –
Ma rannsaicheas sinn air ais fada gu leòir chì sinn nach robh sgoilean anns an Oban gus an ochdamh linn deug. Bha an sgoil bheag a b’ fhaisge air anns a’ Chill Mhóir cóig mìle air falbh, agus tha e coltach gu robh an sgoil sin air an fheadhainn bu shine an Earra-Ghaidheal.
If we research back long enough we will see that there were no schools in Oban until the eighteenth century. The closest little school was in Kilmore five miles away, and it appears that that school was one of the oldest in Argyll. td. 363

module.p:
In modern Gaelic, gu leòr can also function as an (exocentric, i.e. ‘headless’) generic quantity noun compound –
Tha gu leòr uisge ann. There is enough water.
Fhuair i gu leòr de na h-ùbhlan She got enough of the apples.

section.p:
On its own –
Dh’òl Raonaid gu leòr. Rachel drank enough/plenty.
Tha gu leòr aig Màiri. Mary has enough/plenty.
Chaidh gu leòr a sgrìobhadh air a’ chuspair seo cheana [...]
Plenty has already been written about that topic [...] td. 241
Ach tha gu leòr tha ag obair annta, agus a’ làn thuigsinn ciamar a tha iad ag obair, agus faodaidh iad sin feum mhór a dheanamh dhuinn.
But there are plenty [of people] who work in them and understand fully how they work, and these can be of great use to us. td. 213

With a genitive modifier –
Dh’òl Raonaid gu leòr uisge. Rachel drank enough/plenty of water.
Tha gu leòr chon aig Màiri. Mary has enough/plenty of dogs.
Bhiodh gu leòr feòla ann do ’n triùir aca.
There would be enough meat for the three of them. td. 377
’Se bhochdainn a nise nach eil gu leòr leabhraichean aca anns na cànainean aca fhéin.
The misfortune is now that they do not have enough books in their own languages. td. 216
Bha gu leòr de dhaoine ainmeil san sgìre againne ri mo chuimhne fhìn, gun luaidh air na ginealaichean roimhe sin.
There were plenty of famous people in our district in my own memory, to say nothing of the generations before that. td. 112 nb. Note the use of ‘de’ here rather than plain genitive.

The preposition de with a definite noun –
Dh’òl Raonaid gu leòr den fhìon. Rachel drank enough of the wine.
Tha gu leòr de mo choin aig Màiri. Mary has enough of my dogs.
Nuair a bha mi ’nam bhalach òg bha gu leòr de na sgeulachdan sin air an aithris anns an dachaidh san d’fhuair mi m’ àrach [...]
When I was a little boy plenty of those stories were told in the home in which I was brought up [...] td. 312

With a prepositional pronoun –
Dh’òl Raonaid gu leòr dheth. Rachel drank enough of it.
Tha gu leòr dhiubh aig Màiri. Mary has enough/plenty of them.
Bheireadh e a’ mhòr-chuid dhen iasg dha na bochdan, agus ann an 1927 bha gu leòr dhiubh san sgìre againne.
He would give most of the fish to the poor, and in 1927 there was enough of them in our district. td. 112
